docs.text:
Thomas Maher


In New Alexandria, PA, long ago.




These pages summarize software I've written that can be found on 
my github page
  


Education




B.S. Chemical Engineering, Penn State 1996




Experience




University of Pittsburgh School of Dental Medicine- Systems Programmer - Pittsburgh, PA (7/2010-Present)


University of Wisconsin Department of Botany - Information Processing Consultant - Madison, WI (1/2006-7/2010)


Penn State University Department of Computer Science and Engineering - Senior Systems Analyst State College, PA (8/2004-6/2005)


University of Wisconsin Department of Family Medicine - Information Processing Consultant Madison, WI (4/2001-7/2003)


Information Management Consultants, Inc. - Web Developer - McLean, VA (1/1998-4/2000)




Skills




Languages: Java, Python, Perl, SQL, R, PHP, Ruby, HTML/CSS/Javascript, C, Objective-C, shell, markdown, braille


Frameworks: LAMP, J2EE, webapp2, rails, flask, laravel, android, shiny, AWS


Systems: Linux, OSX, arduino, raspberry pi, Sun


Databases: MySQL, SQLite, Postgres, Google Data Store

Web apps running on Google App Engine






http://fixamfm.appspot.com/






http://fixwdc.appspot.com/






http://wisconsinherbarium.appspot.com/










Ruby on Rails apps running on Heroku






Caution: Heroku can take a minute to warm up:






https://aqueous-bayou-3129.herokuapp.com/carriers/

R data package Rufosightings




Install it in R like this:








library(devtools)
install_github(
botanyhelp/Rufosightings
)
library(Rufosightings)
dim(Rufosightings)
head(Rufosightings)








Licensing






Almost all of the code found here has an open source license usually found at the top of source code files. 






Many of these applications have data that are thankfully provided by wikipedia editors and shared under this license: 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Text_of_Creative_Commons_Attribution-ShareAlike_3.0_Unported_License
 
https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/us/

Databases


Google Data Store






Three App Engine web apps use the Google Data Store for persistence:






http://fixwdc.appspot.com/






http://fixamfm.appspot.com/
  
(code on github)






http://wisconsinherbarium.appspot.com/
  
(code on github)










Postgres






Postgres database for Rails application






This Ruby on Rails web application run on Heroku and takes a minute to start:






https://aqueous-bayou-3129.herokuapp.com/carriers/
  
(code on github)






The Rails way of 
convention over configuration
 has us put the database details in the application configuration.  This application has the instructions for Heroku to create the Postgres database and schema for us in 
schema.db
 and 
database.yml
  Details about how to install and configure the Postgres database server are required to run this RoR application on a 
local linux box
 (instead of Heroku) because it expects a local Postgres database server (like the one it finds when deployed on Heroku).  Those details (for CentOS 6 linux) are available on github.  










MySQL




Wisconsin Herbarium

Those details (for CentOS 6 linux) are available on github.

docs.text:
Python




Software below has very short summary, link (if available) and link to code on github




Google App Engine Wisconsin Herbarium


http://wisconsinherbarium.appspot.com/


(code on github)


Python web application 
Fix AM FM


http://fixamfm.appspot.com/


(code on github)


Python web application 
Fix WDC


http://fixwdc.appspot.com/


Albumartmaker


Creates new 300x300 PNG file in the current directory: test.png


python piller2.py






Requires modules Image, ImageDraw, and texwrap


Will use ImageFont if you have them (/usr/share/fonts/bitstream-vera/Vera.ttf)




(code on github)


Searchyumrepos


Search yum software repositories for your list of software.


python searchyumrepos.py anaconda




(code on github)


Gmailer


Short python script to use gmail to send email


(code on github)


Ucscdiskspacer


Program to report total size, in bytes, of UCSC genome browser databases


python ucsc_disk_spacer.py danRer5 hg19




(code on github)


Ucscquery


Python standalone program to query UCSC Genome Browser Mysql database




Requires module MySQLdb


Requires internet access




This program performs steps that can be run manually like this:


mysql --user=genome --host=genome-mysql.cse.ucsc.edu -A
mysql
 use mm9;
Database changed
mysql
 select * from knownCanonical;




(code on github)


Botitwebmaker


Python program that generates HTML web site from a directory of image files.  Generated the HTML found here:


http://botit.botany.wisc.edu/


(code on github)


QRCode


ruby qrHTMLandPNGmaker.rb 
 rb.txt
python qrHTMLmaker.py 
 qr_codes.html




The ruby requires some modules that are probably not present. Install them with gem like this:


gem install rqrcode
gem install rqrcode_png




(code on github)

docs.text:
Java


Android applications


See a dozen android applications written in java

/software/android/


Herbjava


Wisconsin Herbarium tomcat web database application.  This code, when running, will perform very similarly to the existing perl, python and OTS web servers running here:


http://www.botany.wisc.edu/wisflora/


http://wisconsinherbarium.appspot.com/


http://herbarium.wisc.edu/


(code on github)


This application is 
not running anywhere
 to my knowledge.  As a standard tomcat servlet application, it is a port of existing production web servers.  The documentation on github has enough deployment details to get it started again using existing database schema.

docs.text:
Javascript


Awesomplete javascript autocompletion with 28510 gene symbols


This 
short web form
 selects and displays candidate gene symbols that you start typing with auto-completion.  It selects candidate gene symbols from a long list of 28510 genes.  This javascript was used to limit form submissions to only the list of genes that will be considered by Michigan's excellent 
locuszoom
 program.


Uses Lea Verou's 
Awesomplete
 easy to use and totally awesome little javascript library.  


(code on github)


UCSC Genome Browser dynamic custom track documentation


Adding dynamic javascript to a UCSC genome browser custom track documentation file is possible. 


(code on github)


Agemaker age calculating offline web app


http://www.pitt.edu/~twm11/agemaker.html


The application logic is written in Javascript and uses the entered birthdate to calculate the current age to one decimal place (for data entry).  This application is an offline web app which means that it will continue to work even after your Internet connection dies (on all modern browers). 


The javascript, HTML5 and everything is in one file, agemaker.html:  
(code on github)
docs.title: Javascript

This javascript was used to limit form submissions to only the list of genes that will be considered by Michigan's excellent  locuszoom  program.  Uses Lea Verou's  Awesomplete  easy to use and totally awesome little javascript library.    (code on github)

docs.text:
R


R programming certificates


R biostatistics training


R package Rufosightings


Use R to install and run it like this: 


library(devtools)
install_github(
botanyhelp/Rufosightings
)
library(Rufosightings)
ufo_byexactdate()
ufo_byexactdate(20100704)
dim(Rufosightings)
Rufosightings[Rufosightings$sighted_at_year==
1950
,]
Rufosightings[Rufosightings$sighted_at_year==
1942
,]$description
Rufosightings[Rufosightings$sighted_at_year==
1942
,]$duration
Rufosightings[Rufosightings$sighted_at_year==
1942
,]$shape
levels(Rufosightings$shape)
Rufosightings[Rufosightings$location_city==
 Slickville
,]
library(dplyr)
glimpse(Rufosightings)
select(Rufosightings,c(location_city,shape,description)) %
% filter(location_city==
 Miami
) %
% filter(shape==
 cigar
)
docs.title: R

docs.text: R biostatistics training
docs.title: R programming certificates

install_github( botanyhelp/Rufosightings )

Rufosightings[Rufosightings$sighted_at_year== 1950 ,]
Rufosightings[Rufosightings$sighted_at_year== 1942 ,]$description
Rufosightings[Rufosightings$sighted_at_year== 1942 ,]$duration
Rufosightings[Rufosightings$sighted_at_year== 1942 ,]$shape
levels(Rufosightings$shape)
Rufosightings[Rufosightings$location_city==  Slickville ,]
library(dplyr)
glimpse(Rufosightings)
select(Rufosightings,c(location_city,shape,description)) % % filter(location_city==  Miami ) % % filter(shape==  cigar )

docs.text:
Ruby


Herokucarriers




Be patient: heroku dymo startup takes a few seconds
:




https://aqueous-bayou-3129.herokuapp.com/carriers/


(code on github)


QRCode


This ruby code creates png formatted images of the QR codes. It also dumps text which can be used to create an HTML/CSS version of the QR code.


The ruby requires some modules that are probably not present. Install them with gem like this:


gem install rqrcode
gem install rqrcode_png






NOTICE that the URLs are 
hardcoded into the ruby
.


NOTICE that the file qr.txt produced by the ruby is a 
hardcoded input filename
 in the python.


The whole thing was run like this:




ruby qrHTMLandPNGmaker.rb 
 rb.txt
python qrHTMLmaker.py 
 qr_codes.html




After running the ruby program, six new 300x300 PNG-formatted images will be created in the current directory. The output HTML from the python can be dropped right into any HTML file and will display the QR codes.


code on github
docs.title: Ruby

python qrHTMLmaker.py   qr_codes.html  After running the ruby program, six new 300x300 PNG-formatted images will be created in the current directory. The output HTML from the python can be dropped right into any HTML file and will display the QR codes.  code on github

docs.text:
Content


Multilingual and right to left HTML5


http://www.pitt.edu/~twm11/hebrew.html


(code on github)


It displays the hebrew language and instructs the browser to present it using a right-to-left reading orientation which is proper for right to left languages like hebrew.


Notice in your browser that it 
selects
 the text using the 
right to left
 orientation, not like with English and other left to right languages.


Two languages on one page


One page of HTML, two languages:


http://www.pitt.edu/~twm11/russian.html


(code on github)


Offline web application: Agemaker age calculating web page


http://www.pitt.edu/~twm11/agemaker.html


This web application is an 
offline web app
 such that, when you revisit this URL later, 
when you have no Internet connection
, it still works (on all modern web browsers).


(code on github)

docs.text:
Ios


iOS7 Objective-C iPhone App Nuclides


The 
Nuclides iPhone App
 was constructed using Objective-C in xCode using iOS7 as it was during construction, circa February 2014.  This application behaves very similarly to the 
Nuclides Android app
 available on Google Play.  The Nuclides iPhone App is 
not available
 on the Apple App Store.


(code on github)


iOS7 Objective-C iPhone App Deadtapes


Deadtapes is available on the Apple App Store:


https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/deadtapes/id838487529?mt=8


It works very similarly to the Deadshowfinder Android app on the 
/software/android.md
 page.  They help you find out exactly which show your tape was made from.
docs.title: Ios

This application behaves very similarly to the  Nuclides Android app  available on Google Play.  The Nuclides iPhone App is  not available  on the Apple App Store.  (code on github)

docs.text:
Certificates


Certificate Links




PH525.1x: Statistics and R for the Life Sciences Certificate


PH525.2x: Introduction to Linear Models and Matrix Algebra Certificate


PH525.4x: Introduction to Bioconductor Certificate


PH525.1x: Data Analysis for Life Sciences 1: Statistics and R Certificate


SPU30x: Super-Earths and Life Certificate


PH525.2x: Data Analysis for Life Sciences 2: Introduction to Linear Models and Matrix Algebra Certificate




Certificate Details


Enrolled in and completed these ten online courses during 2015 and 2016.  Super-Earths and Life was presented by 
Dimitar Sasselov, Professor of Astronomy, Harvard University
.  The other nine were presented by 
Rafael Irizarry, Professor of Biostatistics, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health
.  These courses cover R programming, statistics and biology.






PH525.1x: Statistics and R for the Life Sciences






PH525.2x: Introduction to Linear Models and Matrix Algebra






PH525.4x: Introduction to Bioconductor






PH525.5x Case Study: RNA-seq data analysis






PH525.6x Case Study: Variant Discovery and Genotyping






PH525.7x Case Study: ChIP-seq data analysis






PH525.8x Case study: DNA methylation data analysis






PH525.1x: Data Analysis for Life Sciences 1: Statistics and R






SPU30x: Super-Earths and Life






PH525.2x: Data Analysis for Life Sciences 2: Introduction to Linear Models and Matrix Algebra






I am speechless and on my knees with gratitude for these courses and the scientists and staff that created them.  The online 
edX Platform
 might be the best online training platform available.  The biostatistics courses are based on this book, available free:


Data Analysis for the Life Sciences, Rafael A Irizarry and Michael I Love


..and also here on github:


github.com/genomicsclass


I completed 8 of these courses on time and with scores high enough to earn a certificate.  For two classes, ChIP-seq data analysis and DNA methylation data analysis, scores were too low to earn a certificate.  Links to certificates and detailed information of performance are shown below for all ten completed courses.  I am presently continuing to pursue knowledge and skills in these deep waters of statistics, biology, data analysis and R programming.

docs.title: Certificate Links

docs.text:
Enrolled in and completed these ten online courses during 2015 and 2016.  Super-Earths and Life was presented by  Dimitar Sasselov, Professor of Astronomy, Harvard University .  The other nine were presented by  Rafael Irizarry, Professor of Biostatistics, Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health .  These courses cover R programming, statistics and biology.    PH525.1x: Statistics and R for the Life Sciences    PH525.2x: Introduction to Linear Models and Matrix Algebra    PH525.4x: Introduction to Bioconductor    PH525.5x Case Study: RNA-seq data analysis    PH525.6x Case Study: Variant Discovery and Genotyping    PH525.7x Case Study: ChIP-seq data analysis    PH525.8x Case study: DNA methylation data analysis    PH525.1x: Data Analysis for Life Sciences 1: Statistics and R    SPU30x: Super-Earths and Life    PH525.2x: Data Analysis for Life Sciences 2: Introduction to Linear Models and Matrix Algebra    I am speechless and on my knees with gratitude for these courses and the scientists and staff that created them.  The online  edX Platform  might be the best online training platform available.  The biostatistics courses are based on this book, available free:  Data Analysis for the Life Sciences, Rafael A Irizarry and Michael I Love  ..and also here on github:  github.com/genomicsclass  I completed 8 of these courses on time and with scores high enough to earn a certificate.  For two classes, ChIP-seq data analysis and DNA methylation data analysis, scores were too low to earn a certificate.  Links to certificates and detailed information of performance are shown below for all ten completed courses.  I am presently continuing to pursue knowledge and skills in these deep waters of statistics, biology, data analysis and R programming.
